bestBHT.bht: The Apostle Paul's gratitude stems from hearing about the Colossian believers' faith in Christ Jesus and their love for all the saints. Although he hadn't visited them, he was thankful to have heard of their faith and love. Their faith was characterized by its steadfastness and sincerity, while their love extended to both present and absent believers. These expressions of faith and love serve as a testimony and reflection of the grace of God, prompting us to show love by serving and supporting one another.

Henry Alford: The facts which he heard, not the fact of his hearing, were the ground of his thanksgiving."
The love which ye have towards all the saints.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Having heard." The language implies that he had only heard of, and not seen, them.
Compare Romans 1:8, where like language is used of a Church which he had not at the time visited.
Love . . . to all—the absent, as well as those present.
Albert Barnes: This does not prove that Paul had never been at Colossae, or that he did not establish the church there, for he uses a similar expression respecting the church at Ephesus Ephesians 1:15, of which he was undoubtedly the founder.
The meaning is, that he had heard of their faith at that time, or of their perseverance in faith and love.

Nothing could be more acceptable information respecting them to one who himself so ardently loved the church; and nothing could have furnished better evidence that they were influenced by the true spirit of religion; compare 1 John 3:14.
John Calvin: Gifts of God that are so excellent ought to have such an effect upon us as to stir us up to love them wherever they appear.

He employs the expression, love towards the saints, not with the view of excluding others, but because, in proportion as any one is joined to us in God, we ought to embrace him the more closely with special affection.

True love, therefore, will extend to mankind universally, because they all are our flesh, and created in the image of God, but in respect of degrees, it will begin with those who are of the household of faith.
Philip Schaff: Having heard. 'After hearing,' rather than, 'since we heard,' or, 'because we heard.'"
Your faith in Christ Jesus. He is the sphere and object of the faith; comp. Ephesians 1:15."
The love which ye have to all the saints. The Italics of the E. V. are unnecessary, since the better supported reading gives 'which ye have,' thus emphasizing the tact that they possess it.
Archibald T. Robertson: Aorist active participle of ακουω of antecedent action to ευχαριστουμεν."
No article is needed before εν as it is a closely knit phrase and bears the same sense as the objective genitive in Galatians 2:16 (δια πιστεως Χριστου Ιησου, by faith in Christ Jesus)."
There is a real distinction here between εν (sphere or basis) and εις (direction towards), though they are often identical in idea.
John Gill: Their faith in Christ...their soundness and steadfastness in it, and their sincere and constant profession of it.
The grace of love itself, which is a fruit of the Spirit implanted in regeneration, and is an evidence of the new birth.
The effects of love...in serving one another in love, by relieving in necessity, sympathizing in distress, praying with and for one another.

bhtAttempts.bht: The Apostle Paul expresses his gratitude upon hearing about the Colossian believers' faith in Christ Jesus and their love for all the saints. The fact that he had heard of their faith and love, even though he had not yet visited them, was the basis for his thanksgiving. This highlights the power and impact of their faith and love, which were not only important in their own lives but also served as a testimony to others. The Colossians' faith was characterized by its soundness and steadfastness, and their love extended not only to those present but even to the absent. These qualities of faith and love should be cherished and expressed towards all believers, reflecting the grace of God within us and showcasing the effects of love through service and compassion.

The Apostle Paul's gratitude stems from hearing about the Colossian believers' faith in Christ Jesus and their love for all the saints. Although he hadn't visited them, he was thankful to have heard of their faith and love. Their faith was characterized by its steadfastness and sincerity, while their love extended to both present and absent believers. These expressions of faith and love serve as a testimony and reflection of the grace of God, prompting us to show love by serving and supporting one another.

Upon hearing of the Colossian believers' faith in Christ Jesus and their love for all the saints, the Apostle Paul was filled with gratitude. Even though he had not yet visited them, the reports he received about their faith and love were the grounds for his thanksgiving. Their faith was characterized by its firmness and devotion, while their love extended to both present and absent believers. These virtues serve as a testament to the transformative power of God's grace, inspiring us to show love and support to one another.

Filled with gratitude, Paul heard about the Colossian believers' faith in Christ Jesus and their love for all the saints. Even though he had not yet visited them, their faith and love were the basis for his thanksgiving. Their faith, characterized by steadfastness and sincerity, demonstrated their commitment to Christ. Their love extended beyond the present, encompassing both absent and present believers. These virtues reflect the transformative power of God's grace, prompting believers to serve and support one another in love.

Upon hearing of the Colossian believers' faith in Christ Jesus and their love for all the saints, the Apostle Paul expressed his gratitude. Even though he had only heard of them and not yet visited, their faith and love were the grounds for his thanksgiving. Their faith exhibited steadfastness and sincerity, while their love extended to both absent and present believers. This highlights the transformative power of God's grace, inspiring believers to serve and support one another in love.
